banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Poems of war, peace, women, power
videoData.socialTitle: Poems of war, peace, women, power

nodes.whatOthersSay: In these poems, it’s no longer necessary to speak in argument convincing sentences; the fact of her being, speaking, the fact of her family’s, her communities’, the fact of women surviving in Palestine, in Iraq, in New Orleans, is argument enough.
nodes.whoTheyAre: In her poems and plays, Suheir Hammad blends the stories and sounds of her Palestinian-American heritage with the vibrant language of Brooklyn to create a passionately modern voice.
nodes.whyListen:
Suheir Hammad is the author of Breaking Poems, recipient of a 2009 American Book Award and the Arab American Book award for Poetry 2009. Her other books are ZaatarDiva; Born Palestinian, Born Black; and Drops of This Story. Her work has been widely anthologized and also adapted for theater.

Her produced plays include Blood Trinity and breaking letter(s), and she wrote the libretto for the multimedia performance Re-Orientalism. An original writer and performer in the Tony-winning Russell Simmons Presents Def Poetry Jam on Broadway, Suheir appears in the 2008 Cannes Film Festival Official Selection Salt of This Sea. She is the Artist in Residency at the NYU’s APA Institute for 2010.

videoData.description: Poet Suheir Hammad performs two spine-tingling spoken-word pieces: "What I Will" and "break (clustered)" -- meditations on war and peace, on women and power. Wait for the astonishing line: "Do not fear what has blown up. If you must, fear the unexploded."
videoData.socialDescription: Poet Suheir Hammad performs two spine-tingling spoken-word pieces: "What I Will" and "break (clustered)" -- meditations on war and peace, on women and power. Wait for the astonishing line: "Do not fear what has blown up. If you must, fear the unexploded."

cues.text: I will not dance to your war drum.
I will not lend my soul nor my bones to your war drum.
I will not dance to that beating.
I know intimately that skin you are hitting.
I will not dance to your drummed-up war.
I will not pop, spin, break for you.
I will not hate for you
I will not kill for you.
Especially I will not die for you.
I will not mourn the dead with murder nor suicide.
I will not side with you or dance to bombs
Life is a right, not collateral or casual.
I will not forget where I come from.
I will craft my own drum.
and our chanting will be dancing.
I will not lend my name nor my rhythm to your beat.
I will dance and resist and dance and persist and dance.
This heartbeat is louder than death.
What's up TED people? Let me hear you make some noise.
I've been wrong a lot lately.
I mean, I've been saying I've been prepping.
What that means is prepping my outfit,
trying to figure out what I'm coming behind
It preps you. It aims you.
So I am going to read a poem
But I'm going to need you
to just sit for like 10 minutes
and hold a woman who is not here.
You don't need to say her name out loud, you can just hold her.
Unwritten books predicted the future, projected the past.
Which male child will perish a new day?
War and tooth, enameled salted lemon childhoods.
All colors run, none of us solid.
Don't look for shadow behind me. I carry it within.
I live cycles of light and darkness.
I see now, I never was one and not the other.
I think now I never was pure.
One woman loses 15, maybe 20, members of her family.
One woman searches rubble. One woman feeds on trash.
One woman shoots her face. One woman shoots her husband.
One woman gives birth to a baby.
One woman gives birth to borders.
One woman no longer believes love will ever find her.
placed where they're not from, don't want to be missed.
or we mean nothing at all.
Precipice running to and running from human beings.
